Telinga Pro5W with Stereo DAT microphone. No filtering. No noise from traffic but a constant sound from the nearby sea.

A male blackbird was singing his territorial song/call on the top of a spruce.  The barking voice in the background belongs to a roe deer (Capreolus capreolus).
Recording is made with a video camera placed at the nest of a white-tailed sea eagle at the altitude of about 25 m above ground. Recording is not modified in any way. The microphone is placed under the nest.
Habitat is a mixed forest with broadleaved and coniferous trees with some wetland.

recordings.file-name: XC635192-210330_2994 1004 Amsel. D, B, Spandauer Forst. Stephan Risch.mp3
recordings.rmk: Near forest canal "Kuhlanke".
Blackbird singing at dusk in a quiet backyard in Berlin City near Wröhmännerpark.

Though this vocalisation starts out normally for a blackbird, after a while (around 1:45 ), the bird started to repeat phrases in an almost song thrush-like way, which I thought was interesting. The song also got a bit quieter then.
One alarm call right at the end, when the bird decided it was time for bed.

Some noise reduction done to reduce noise from distant motorway, and some handling noise clipped out.
Blackbird and spring!

Fight alarm/thrill - often given by the species when flushed, although it is probable that this vocalisation arises from other circumstances also, as it is detected most mornings by our semi-permanent recording setup. recordings.loc: Christiansø, Ertholmene, Capital Region of Denmark
recordings.rmk:
Filter: Noise redution. This day there was on the island: 100.000 Song Thrush (Turdus philomelos). 4.000

recordings.loc: Royal Victoria Park, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Mimicry of various emergency vehicle sirens. This is almost certainly the same bird that I recorded a few days before in XC574956. For an explanation of the siren sounds please see that recording.

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 attached strapped to a fence. Edited to reduce light vehicle sounds and EQ adjusted below 1500 Hz to reduce the general background sounds that are starting to appear by this time in the morning.

The other recordings that I made this morning of this bird are:

XC583788

XC583789

XC583790

recordings.loc: Hagenheim, Im Kleinfeld, Hofstetten,   Landsberg am Lech, Oberbayern, Bayern
recordings.file-name: XC579541-AMSEL, Kikeriki 1  24.04.2020  Hheim, Kleinfeld  5_32-5_47  VOC_200424-0644 g.mp3
recordings.rmk: This male Blackbird developped during springtime strophes with a remarkable loud sound leap (Tonsprung), just before he ended with an even higher pitched squiggel. Therefore we call him "Kikeriki-Amsel" (cock-a-doodle-doo-Blackbird). At the moment he still sings this strophes sometimes very early in the morning. When I took this recording, he sat for a long time on a crest, at the blind end of Kleinfeld.
Tascam DR05 and Dodotronic parabole
Perched on rooftop. Evening in village. High-pass filter 75 Hz 48 dB. Equipment: Sony PCM-D100.

recordings.loc: Royal Victoria Park, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Mimicry of various emergency vehicle sirens. There are three sounds that are imitated: the "wail" e.g. at 0:41, the "yelp" e.g. at 0:31 and "piercer" e.g. at 0:26. These are the standard Whelan sirens used by the police and by ambulances travelling to the Royal United Hospital in Bath which is just a few hundred metres up the road.

It is interesting to see how the Blackbird incorporates the sounds into its song. In this case the basis of the song is dominated by siren sounds with fewer verses sounding like a typical Blackbird verse. Even those verses with normal structure appear to have been influenced by the sirens and have lots of repeated notes and occasional snippets of "yelp" and parts of the "wail" (e.g. the opening verse and 0:17). 

An actual "wail" siren is a continuous sound which rises and falls in pitch. When the Blackbird tries to copy this sound it seemingly cannot replicate the continuous nature of it; the final result is 10 or so shorter notes strung together to give the impression of a siren. This is best seen by looking at the sonogram. 

In addition to the sirens, this bird may also mimic a Magpie at 6:33.7 and the sound of a metallic object being struck at 3:43. 

Noted as male based on plumage.  

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 microphone handheld. Very lightly edited below 300 Hz to reduce some background rumble and handling noise.

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).
HP Filter 1000Hz, -6dB, Telinga Pro 5 + Mixpre 3

recordings.file-name: XC562373-turdus merula 4 palacio de viana 01-05-2019 (160 kbps).mp3
recordings.rmk:
Recital de mirlo grabado antes de amanecer. el ejemplar es uno de los machos residentes que ha elegido como atalaya de canto una gran encina que hay en la zona ajardinada del palacio de Viana. durante unos días sus llamadas nocturnas eran más insistentes, seguramente por tener a su hembra incubando una segunda puesta y disponer de más tiempo para marcar el territorio. Como sabía que en cuanto nacieran los polluelos cantaría bastante menos aproveché esos días para grabarlo en el silencio de la noche. Además de vez en cuándo se escuchan los chillidos de algún murciélago que pasa y el llamado de otro macho de mirlo que responde en la lejanía.
  Es sabido que los mirlos urbanos modifican sus horas de canto para evitar los momentos de mayor ruido de tráfico, por eso éste canta a horas tan intempestivas.

  Grabación realizada a 160 kbps.
